												The top-rated helpful review compares this game positively to 3D shmups like Star Fox and urges the reader to purchase this game immediately if they enjoy the others. Don't do that.Since the comparison to Star Fox has already been made, I'm going to roll with it. We're going to be focusing on the similarities and differences between this game and Star Fox 64, which might seem unfair once I get into it, but 64 is eighteen years old and this game came out this year.First off, the flying. Your ship (no matter which one you select,) has no real weight to it. It floats gleefully around the screen with such speed that it highlights more especially than anything the stirring lack of actual control you have over it and the lack of any real animation to it. The ship floats where you point it and that's it. No maneuvering, no complexity of control, and no real animation to the motion besides a slight tilt in the direction you're heading.Okay, the flying's not great, but 3D shmups are more about the shooting anyway. Star Fox 64 had satisfyingly fast shooting with incrimental power upgrades for your lasers. This game SORT OF has a similar upgrade, but it is automatically collected - no challenge there - and only serves to slightly speed up your INCREDIBLY SLOW AND INACCURATE SHOOTING. Your shots don't arc based on motion or follow the angle of your ship, they go forward on a fixed line, meaning you need to line up perfectly with your enemy to shoot them. This would be a small flaw if your ship didn't block most of the screen and make actually seeing and lining up with an enemy an incredibly difficult effort that ultimately only serves to crash your ship into the target and not actually give any meaningful award or feedback for shooting the target down.The screen is locked exactly as it is, so your range of motion is incredibly limited. This wouldn't be an issue considering the complete LACK OF DIFFICULTY for most of the game, but sooner rather than later, enemies and their attacks start tracking you. With the screen locked as it is and your ship as floaty and unresponsive as it is, you very quickly start losing life to attacks you've got almost no chance of escaping. This is what we call ARTIFICIAL DIFFICULTY. It's when a stupidly easy game makes a stupid and hamfisted attempt to make itself not so stupidly easy.There's little to no variety in the levels. Honestly, the major difference between one level and the next is what enemy or threat you're meant to be shooting or avoiding. There's briefly an in-door segment with metal walls to avoid, but it's not contextualized as a huge enemy ship or planet or base or anything, and once it's done you're back to the completely linear space hallway.The visual style is incredibly lazy. Nothing looks interesting or memorable in any way, and the utter lack of animation beyond direct motion kills any sort of interest the bland designs and lazy attacks might generate.I'd like to say there's something positive to this game to help redeem it or maybe make it more aggrieving that the rest is so lazy and boring, but there isn't.I can't put in the effort to be mad at a game that didn't have any effort put into at all.TL;DR Slow, boring, lazy, ugly, and uninpsired. No matter what other games you enjoy, pass this one up. It's not worth your time, let alone your money.0/10 (NOT WORTH RATING)

												Here we have another game that can be summed up in a single word: YIKES!It's cute that Sun Blast's store description not only has the gall to claim that it was inspired by Star Fox, Space Harrier, and Panzer Dragoon, but it also says that it's "the best 3d space shooter on Steam".Sun Blast was inspired by a dumpster fire. Never before have I played a shooter with such poor mechanics, sluggish controls, and awful mission-design. Dodging enemy ships and their bullets should be a relatively simple task, but instead it's messy and somewhat convoluted. This can be attributed to the odd perspective. It's not always clear where objects are in relation to the player-ship. So this results in lots of collisions. The bosses tend to have homing weapons, and they're exceedingly frustrating to deal with. Why? Because the player-ship can't maneuver around them, and the angle makes it difficult to tell where the homing shots are heading.In shootemups, dodging a single bullet should be as easy as breathing. The developer makes the game more difficult by increasing the speed of that bullet, adding more of them, giving them unique properties, and so on. It's the constantly building intensity that keeps these games challenging. Sun Blast somehow manages to accomplish the opposite. Dodging a single bullet is far more trouble than in any other game I've played. The missions are exceedingly generic and dull. For the most part they're also extremely easy, except for the bosses. Whenever I had to replay the last few stages, because I died at the boss, all I could do was nod my head and think "Yep. I expected this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t."  If I spend enough time with Sun Blast, eventually I could learn to handle it's many terrible qualities. But why? This game suffers from a total dearth of entertainment value. Before I forget, let's take a look at this statement: "the best 3d space shooter on Steam". I can't claim to know the Steam Store's library well enough to confirm that this is false. However, I will point out that Space Harrier II is available on the service. While it hasn't aged well, and the frame-rate is worse than Sun Blast's, this relic from the 16-bit era is a much better game. I suppose it doesn't include enough "3D" or "space" to fit the criteria, but it might actually be worth your time.

-Quick Review-Sun Blast is a 3d-ish, space shooter-ish, developed by OBLONE Software and released April 2, 2015. In Sun Blast you move up down left or right while shooting and dodging.


Score level 
A Screenshot of Sun Blast
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Warning: This is going to be a salty review. That being said, who knows... maybe you'll like this game more then I did. Maybe Sun Blast will capture your heart... I will admit I haven't played any other "starfox inspired" space shooter games on steam.Story: There is no story. Outside of the flavor text written on this game's store front.


Survival level 
A Screenshot of Sun Blast
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: I don't want to compare this game to star fox because Star fox is a game I actually enjoyed playing, whereas I did not enjoy Sun Blast at all. I would discourage anyone to attempt to play this game with a keyboard, and recommend you turn on auto fire (so you can spam fire while auto firing).Lets just examine each "feature" on the store front:1) Full gamepad supportYes, they even have wii motion controls, for any of you on steam whom have a wiimote.2) Three ship designs to choose from, each with unique look and behaviorOne ship moves right and left a tiny bit faster the then others and up and down slower, one moves up and down a tiny bit faster and left and right slower, and the third moves up and down at a medium pace (so it's not strong in one area and weak in the other)I didn't notice a difference between the ships in any real significant way.3) Fight against stealthy fighters and gigantic starshipsAre there stealthy fighters? Yes, there are about 2 types of star ship fighters, and 3 different types of starship "bosses".4) Huge level selection, from planet orbits to underground tunnels to infested military basesThis is the one I have the problem with. There are only about 4 or 5 different types of levels: Survival levels, shoot down a number of ships levels, dodge and break apart rocks levels, timed levels, any mix of the aforementioned levels... and boss levels.THEN, they reskin the pretty background, and have you do the same levels over, changing the ships on the level, and changing the "NPC" or "target" density.In a game like starfox dynamic events would take place, even if you were playing more of a rain shooter at certin points of the game, you'd need to shoot an enemy chasing after a friendly, sometimes a friendly would save you... There's nothing which changes from level to level. It's either: shooting to get enough kills, or dodging to get through a mine field.5) Replay levels to earn medalsThose are the challenges, and they  relate to:6) Steam achievements and leaderboardsMost people will get this game exclusively for the steam trading cards, for the sake of trading card mills. which... I mean, if that's your goal of this game, you'll get your money's worth, but my review relates to the game itself.In other words the most redeeming qualities for Sun Blast is: wiimote support, the music is good at first but then gets repetitive, and steam trading cards.


Level complete screen 
A Screenshot of Sun Blast
By: Atratzu




Conclusion: Now comes my softening statements of remorse... I've clearly explained why I dislike this game... The problem: someone worked on this game. It's not pretty, it's not fun. But it's cheap, you get trading cards, and at least it's a little different.The problem is there's no real motivation to keep playing, and I don't feel like when I die it was really my fault and could have been avoidable. I use Super Meat Boy as my go-to for samples of "difficult, but fair". It could extend to any number of classic Arcade-styled video games, like Pacman or Galaga.If the only way to get all the achievements and to be GOOD at Sun Blast is to learn the levels like someone would learn Pacman or Galaga, then I guess I'll need to disappoint the creator because I'm not going to put that amount of time into a game like that.Like I said at the start of this review, some people might be interested in trying this game out, and some people might like it; that's okay, I'm glad you enjoy the games you like, but I will be taking my time and playing something else.Thanks for reading my Review. Atratzu out.

												Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Sun Blast with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.       Sun Blast was presented to me in one sentence as “like Starfox 64”. Prior to even redeeming the key I found this an unfair way to represent a new game because Starfox (in my opinion) is the best of the best for that third person arcade shootem’up genre. Putting expectations at that level means that a fully competent title could easily be harshly critiqued or condemned for not being absolutely perfect.       Fortunately, this is not the case for Sun Blast; it is anything but competent. Right from the start the controller mapping is atrocious. O(PS4)/B(360) is NOT the select button, it is the back button. Period. To be fair, that’s nothing a quick remapping would resolve right? Wrong. Attempting to open the remapping section of the options menu hard crashes the game. Every. Single. Time.       At that point I figured I might as well try out the actual game to see if troubleshooting would be worth the effort. Spoiler: it wasn’t. The ship you pilot is MONSTROUS; at any given moment over a fifth of your screen is obstructed by it. Shooting can hardly be called that, when you fire the only feedback is a pitiful streak of blue moving awkwardly towards the center of the screen. And yes I mean the center; the depth of the playing field is so janky that it is almost nauseating trying to figure out where your ship is relative to the debris you’re attempting to shoot or avoid. Not a good experience at all.

												This game is a pretty middle-of-the-road, if entertaining (in an arcade rail-shooter kind of way) third-person space shooter.    I do think the comparisons to Starfox, Panzer Dragoon etc. are just a bit hyperbolic - the game is really only superficially similar to these well-regarded classics. It is ultimately more like a third-person Galaga/Asteroids clones with a few Starfox elements like the tunnel level etc. The graphics and sound are fine, if not technically/artistically impressive, and the controls of the various pilotable spacecraft are very responsive using a X-Box 360 controller. There are several different level types, from needing to destroy a certain number of objects/enemies before the timer runs out, surviving an onslaught of obstacles for a certain amount of time to navigating tunnels, and these tend to repeat with the odd boss-battle ad-nauseum. As I've not invested very much time in the game at this time, I can't comment on later levels.All in all, it's not a bad little arcadey game for 24 cents (the price I paid during a sale), and I've certainly dropped a quarter into far worse arcade machines for a single play, but I would say that it's definitely a harder sell at above $1 or so. At the right price, it's a simple little arcade game that scratches that certain itch in small bursts, but it's not something I can see myself investing a lot of time in.

It requires you to master all forms of gameplay presented.  - Well paced. This game doesn't have a difficulty wall. It gradually eases you into the harder and harder levels. And even as the levels progress, it is preparing you for what's to come.Cons: - Control... No matter your ship, you control like you're flying a blimp - Graphics: The graphics are lacking a bit. I gather that this is an indie game, but everything looks a bit too flat and uninspired. There's no real art direction other than "Standard space shmup."I rather enjoy this game and can see myself playing it quite a bit in the future. That said, it's not the best game I've ever played. 												Ok, so this game has a few flaw, but overall it is an enjoyable experience. I myself am a huge fan of the shmup genre, with Starfox (the original for SNES, not 64) being the first game I ever played to completion, and this game definitely deserves a spot on the shelf with other shmups. Let's get right into it, shall we?Pros: - MUSIC! This game has some of the most up-beat, driving, and overall motivating music I've heard in an indie shmup for a while - Variation: This game doesn't just ask you to shoot everything. It requires you to master all forms of gameplay presented.  - Well paced. This game doesn't have a difficulty wall. It gradually eases you into the harder and harder levels. And even as the levels progress, it is preparing you for what's to come.Cons: - Control... No matter your ship, you control like you're flying a blimp - Graphics: The graphics are lacking a bit. I gather that this is an indie game, but everything looks a bit too flat and uninspired. There's no real art direction other than "Standard space shmup."I rather enjoy this game and can see myself playing it quite a bit in the future. That said, it's not the best game I've ever played. There is certainly better, but for $2, I'm not going to complain.

												Got this game even though the store page said the reviews were "mixed" for this game. The game was on sale for 19 cents and has steam trading cards, so for that price I couldn't resist. The game is very fun. It is basically an on-rails arcade shooter, that starts off really easy but quickly ramps up in difficulty when you get to the boss battles. I was stuck on one of the boss battles but felt really good after I finally beat the level. The music is great and although I think its the same 2 or 3 tracks, It dosen't become annoying. There are pickups on the levels that make it easier to blast enemies, like a faster gun and a shield. The graphics are pretty bad for a game released in 2015. To be honest it looks like a PS2 game and for some reason the game Is locked at 45 fps. Also, when you first launch the game and try to run it in 1920x1080 you'll notice that the screen is cut off. However, if you go to the folder where the game is installed, there is a tool that will fix the problem.  My biggest gripe with the game would be the User Interface and Presentation. There is no real indication of how far along you are in the campaign. When you beat a level it just tales you to the next one. There's no screen that says how many more levels there are. Also there is no way to easily change to another ship, (the game lets you choose from 3 at the beginning of your campaign). These problems however do not negate the fact that the core game at hand is very fun. At full price I don't know if I would feel like I got a value.  There is only about 2-4 hours of gameplay, but for 19 cents I cant complain.

Posted: August 21, 2015
												This is not like Star Fox! After buying this game, I was looking forward to what I thought was the PC's answer to Star Fox. I also didn't see a proper sequel to the Star Fox series coming anytime soon. I doubt that Star Fox Zero (the upcoming one for the Wii U; not sure if that's the exact title) will offer much either.Suffice it to say, I was very disappointed in this. But I suppose there are a few pros. Here's the breakdown:PROS+ Cool textures for the price (I payed $0.24 for it instead of the original $5 price)+ Music is okay and works for the gameCONS- Levels are generic and repetitive. Environments are quite static. I had to double check this page to see if it was EA (Early Access), but it wasn't, and to be fair, even in EA, games usually have more to them. The space levels are the most generic; you either have a static background and a "starfield" whose simplistic particles keep coming towards you monotonously, or you have a planet under you that appears to be a scrolling surface. In short, this is an inferior Star Fox that borrows from its worst parts.- Graphics settings are minimal, consisting only of resolution and a fullscreen toggle.- Checkpoints are thrown at you at the end of boss fights that seem to occur every 4 levels, and you only have 1 life, so if you die during the boss fight, you have to repeat those 4 levels, which is frustrating when you beat some of the more challenging levels.- Powerups don't seem to change anything except for the appearance of your ammo being fired. The purple stuff in your final weapon upgrade wiggles left and right in its trajectory which may slightly increase the radius making it more likely to collide with enemy hitboxes, but not enough to be worth the effort. If you get enough powerups without getting hit too much, you get a shield, but I can't remember if it absorbs 1 damage before collapsing or if it even does that much.- No option to use the mouse to move the ship or to even remap keybindings.CONCLUSIONDon't waste your time, energy, or money on this. It's not worth it. There are far better FREE games out there. I am going to ask for a refund (it sounds like a lot of trouble for $0.24, but they shouldn't be able to profit from this). This game is one way to pass the time, but I know of a better way, go play Solitaire! Sun Blast is not nearly as fun as Star Fox, so don't be fooled.

Posted: August 29, 2015
												Music's alright.  That's about it.  Collision detection is DREADFUL.  No such thing as a near miss in this game.  Patterns are random, yet predictable, and all based on the current ship location.  Could be a great game if it were diversified a bit more, and collision detection detected actual collisions, instead of slamming into thin air.  I gave it an hour, and was annoyed the whole time.  This game is NOTHING like Starfox, Starfox rewarded skill, and had a lot of variety in the levels, and felt like doing more than just flying through a tunnel where the empty space around an object is just as hazardous as the object itself.  I hope I can still get a refund for this crap.
